text: Do you have or know a kid that takes things apart? If you answered yes, then this is for them. I have a three year old that loves to take his toys apart and sometimes destructive in doing so. He will manage to find a screwdriver in the house and take apart some his toys quietly in a corner hoping I don't notice.This toy is a perfect way to cultivate their curiosity and fine motor skills. The biplane comes partially assembled. It's nice that the box stays in tact after you open it up so you can use it to store the parts. The drill uses very common AA batteries, which makes powering this toy fairly easy. If you don't have the batteries you can still use the pieces like manual tools or even simply use your hands. The plastic is thick enough to be durable for the little ones. This is not recommended for infants since the bolts can be choking hazards.When I showed my son the plane he was so excited. He couldn't wait to open it up. The instructions were clear. It wasn't long after we put the batteries in the drill that this neat little biplane to was assembled. He rolled it on the floor a few times and pretended it was flying. After a few minutes he was ready to take it part and put it back together again. He did the over and over for about an hour. This, coming from a kid that can't sit still on his own unless he is thoroughly entertained. This seems to do that for him. The next day he wanted to take it to his grandma's house to "show" her how to put it together. He said "Watch and pay attention Lola!"This toy helps him learn how to use tools, puzzling pieces together, and cleanup after he plays with it. We actually lost one of the bolts for a whole 30 minutes! Good thing we found it or I would have been trying to figure out how to get extra pieces delivered right away. This company does make other toys like this one and we plan on adding to the collection. I highly recommend this to anyone who knows a curious young kid. This will surely tickle his mind. I hope this helps you make a more informed decision. Please let me know if you have any questions and I will do my best to answer them in a timely manner.
author: Tanner L Pollard

text: My 4 year boy is autistic and completely non-verbal but he has a passion for taking things apart and putting them back together.  I have been looking for just the right toy like this and I think this is just about as good as it gets.  It isn't perfect but few things are.  What we love about it:- Came packaged very nicely and with instructions- Is very well made!  Unlike other toys of this kind that I've tried by another company, these plastic pieces are all very solid and sturdy instead of flimsy and bendable.- Is big!  It's bigger than I expected which is nice!  Makes it much easier for little hands to assemble and manipulate the pieces.- The included power screwdriver (which takes two AA batteries) works well and has different screw bits that can be used and swapped out very easily.  I bought other versions of take apart toys from other companies that come with regular screwdrivers but those are still too complicated for my son to operate.  Power was the way to go!- Screwdriver rotates both ways for screwing in and taking out by a small switch on the underside of the barrel.- While a little difficult for my impatient son at first, it's pretty intuitive and he started picking it up quickly.- Fun to play with when it's done!  The propellor spins (not powered) and the wheels roll.Things that could be better:- While it's great that the screwdriver rotates both ways, it can be confusing for a little one to figure out which way it's going on their own.  It would be better with some kind of picture indicator by the switch showing which way takes the screws out and which pushes them in.- I'm so happy that it came with instructions but they're not meant for really little kids.  That's ok, they made sense enough for me to help him the first few times.- It would be really nice if this came with an extra screw or two since if any of these get lost...game over.All in all I really love this toy and so far so does my son!  Well done Battat!!  I did NOT receive this item free or at a discount
author: Kate Mahoney

Cousins wanted to play too (5 and 7 yo). What's also awesome is that it works with the black and decker toy work bench we got him. He can use the drill from this set  to screw in those screws into the work bench.  Love that the parts are interchangeable. He's been putting it together and taking it apart several times a day. It's the toy he's been bringing everywhere.  So happy we made this purchase. Highly recommend!

text: ***I give the team at Amazon a 5 out of 5 stars.***  Here's why.  I ordered the toy for my son for Christmas and it arrived in a day and a half.  When he opened it, he was overjoyed and that is priceless.  However, there was a problem with the toy (I'll get to later), and I had to send it back.  As soon as I clicked the return button I got a confirmation that the toy was on its way to my door.  I got a day and a half later.***I give the Toy a 4 out of 5***.  My 3 year old loves to disassemble and reassemble the plane.  The tools are just right for little hands, and the plane is simple enough for him to put together.  There are interchangeable drill bits, and an electric drill.  All the things you need to engage a child, and keep them happy.  I was also happy that my son felt a sense of accomplishment after he put it together all by himself.  However, the drill didn't work in the forward position, so my son had to use the drill bits sans the drill.***I give Battat a 3 out of 5***.  Battat, I love your toys, and how they inspire creativity in children.  However, I received a plane with a non-functioning drill.  I tried to call your customer service, and received a message that the call volume was too high and I'd have to go online.  I don't mind going on line, but when I did fill out the form, no one got back to me.  I hate returning things when I can easily get the part from you.

text: I really like these toys and this crane was the third one I purchased (after the bi-plane and the car).  This one is easily the most complex of three I've had... really too complex for my 2 y/o (though she does pretty well with both the plane and the car).  Regardless, it would be a great toy for her to grow into if I could have found one that wasn't defective!I've now ordered and returned two of these.  In both cases the thread for the bolt that holds the base of the crane onto the bed of the truck was damaged, making it impossible to properly assemble the vehicle.  I suppose one could force the bolt in, but removing it (or replacing it) with the drill/driver wouldn't work at all.Specifically, it looks like there's a manufacturing problem with the orange truck base causing this single thread to be mis-formed.  It may be you get one that doesn't exhibit this issue... but after two tries I'm giving up.  Assuming you can get a non-defective unit, this looks to be a pretty cool toy.  However, there are a few other issues worth mentioning.  This particular model has a lot of parts, parts that will not all fit back into the box without some creative packing.  So, unless you have some better way to store the toy, this may be a problem.  Note, both the car and bi-plane will easily fit back into the original box (i.e. I can get my toddler to put these away).Hope that helps!

If the drill worked, I would give it 5 stars.  But the drill doesn't work well, and that creates frustration for the child.  The child does not really understand how a drill should or does work, and an inconsistent tool further complicates their understanding.For us, the drill not only lacks the torque, but also often doesn't even spin.  It has issues making proper mechanical contact with the post.So we end up using this by hand, with the help of the tools, since some of the pieces can't be accessed directly by hand.

text: My little brother had a Take-A-Part car back in the 70's that he loved, so I was familiar with the concept. My little grandson, 3, had a blast with this car when he opened it! His dad played with it with him until he understood how it worked and then he took it apart and back together over and over and over and over! The drill is so nice and has a switch to change from making the 'lug nuts and screws' go in or for taking them out. This was a little bit difficult for a young three to understand, but he soon got the hang of it. I highly recommend this toy for your little one. (BTW- my brother still has the 70's model!)

text: Well built for what it is.  Was disappointed that there was no attempt at any degree of challenge or creativity in the assembly process.  I guess times have changed, but the take-apart truck from my childhood was more complex.  In essence it was a box truck with each side panel, front and back panels, wheels plus truck frame and truck cabin being separate pieces.  Each piece needed 2-4 plastic nuts and bolts or wing nuts to assemble (except wheels).  There were real options with which pieces were used where and the results varied in look but not function (truck would still roll and carry stuff regardless).I was also disappointed with this that the screwdriver ends are not all needed.  Wanted him to learn the idea that different tools are needed for different tasks.  The flat head attachment is never needed.  Just would have liked to have seen at least one piece that wouldn't work with phillips and socket.Finally, the cordless screwdriver comes with a warning not to use rechargeable batteries.  That would almost be a deal killer for me had I known.  I'm probably going to go rogue and try them anyway since we don't keep too many disposable AAs around.  I guess they could explode or something, so the boys will probably just have to do it all manually.  One set of new, standard alkaline batteries lasted almost one whole day so that would get expensive, even after the novelty of using it on every item in the house wears off.Despite all the above, still gets 4 stars at it ranks as one of the more successful toys for our boys.

The drill accessories don't clip on in any fashion, so they're only held on by a tiny amount of friction and easily fall off. Each toy in the line has some large plastic bolts and screws, and a toy power drill that uses two AA batteries and different attachments to tighten or loosen bolts and screwsI wanted to like this toy, but the crane arm keeps falling apart when my child plays with it.  The bolts inevitably loosen so that the arm flops around.  Then my toddler uses his hands to unscrew them and pull them apart.  It was also a little difficult to assemble the crane arm for me the first time, and I'm an adult.  The wheels do stay on the truck part and it rolls well.  I think that something like the Take-A-Part car or air plane would be a better option, because the child can still use the drill to take apart the toy, but then it also would stay together during play.My two and half year old got this for Christmas from a relative.  In general, he's too young for this  There aren't any obvious choking hazards.  The bolts are small enough to choke on, but my toddler is old enough that he isn't exploring everything with his mouth.  Rather than dangerous, this toy is not a good fit because at a young age he doesn't grasp the concept of using the drill to tighten and loosen.  He's seen me use power tools before, so he understands the concept.  He seems to want to just hold the drill and pretend to use it on all kinds of things.  But, really, a set of plastic tools would probably be more fun for him to play pretend.  I think an older child, maybe 5 to 7, would enjoy the taking apart and assembling with power tools part.  It is not versatile like a set of blocks.  Instead, all the parts have to go together to make just the crane arm truck put together just so.
